author: Jacob Greber
title: Gen Y to be slugged $100,000 in extra taxes for Canberra's budget failures
text:
The Grattan Institute's John Daley says: "We are embedding the mañana budget." Ryan Stuart Share on twitter by Jacob Greber The federal government's failure to fix a budget based on over-optimistic growth forecasts means young Australians could be slugged an extra $100,000 in taxes over their lifetimes to pay for today's spending commitments, according to new research.
In an analysis of the growing future burden of the Abbott government's decision in May to largely postpone serious budget repair, the Grattan Institute warns that Canberra is now effectively "hoping for the best" on a narrowing deficit.
Predictions in the budget that the surplus would return to balance by the end of the decade rely on a heroic return to rates of economic growth not seen for most of the past 15 years and an ever-rising cash grab from income taxes that will hit younger middle- and low-income households the most, the institute finds.
John Daley, chief executive of the Melbourne-based think tank, said both sides of politics must build community support for changes on tax and spending to close the budget gap.
Given many of the options are politically difficult – such as broadening the goods and services tax, winding back superannuation concessions and changing negative gearing – action is needed today, he argues.
This means taking "tough choices" to the next election, rather than ruling them out, Mr Daley indicated.
"If you don't tell people how big the problem is, how are you going to get their permission to fix it," Mr Daley said.
Mr Daley said a key risk in the May budget was that it assumes an unlikely return to surplus within four to five years – effectively entrenching a complacency about the scale of the medium-term fiscal challenge facing the country.
 "Those optimistic budget forecasts provide justification for doing nothing," Mr Daley told The Australian Financial Review . "We are embedding the mañana budget."
The report challenges the Abbott government's argument of recent month that there is no longer any urgency to the budget repair task, despite a growing list of headwinds, including falling wages growth, a collapsed terms of trade, rising demands for services from an aging population and a widening infrastructure shortfall that is hamstringing the economy's productivity.
The shift in strategy from last year's focus on debt and deficits "makes it easier for the government to fix it another time; or more accurately, say there's 'nothing to see here. It'll all be right'," he said.
However, as shown in the Grattan research report – Fiscal Challenges for Australia – Treasurer Joe Hockey has shifted the lion's share of his anticipated budget repair over the next four years onto the burden of fiscal drag, or the process by which wage hikes push workers into higher tax brackets.
Also known as bracket creep, the process means the Federal government will extract an extra $25 billion from payrolls by 2018-19, equivalent to more than half of total budget repair job.
Spending moderation, by comparison, will deliver just $12 billion in improvements to the bottom line, which is currently around $41 billion in deficit, the institute said.
The report, co-authored by Grattan fellow Danielle Wood, estimates that for every year that the government delivers a deficit of $40 billion – it essentially borrows from future generations to the tune of $10,000 via extra taxes.
The current run of budget deficits began in 2008-09 and is expected by Treasury to remain in place until no sooner than 2019-20, with the expected improvement heavily reliant on economic growth rebounding to 3.5 per cent in 2017-18 and 2018-19 – a forecast that has been heavily questioned in recent days by the International Monetary Fund , and former Treasury secretary Martin Parkinson .
"Based on the government's numbers, a decade of accumulated deficits means we are effectively saying to households aged 25 to 34 today that they will pay an extra $80,000 in tax over their lifetimes," Mr Daley said.
"If the government is wrong, and we think they are, it'll be more like $100,000.
"And that's for a generation not getting much in the way of free kicks out of the housing market or assets that they own."
The Grattan research exposes the degree to which succussive governments have consistently over-estimated the budget position over the past five years, with only the 2009 budget – prepared in the midst of the worst global economic crisis since the Great Depression – coming close to being on target four years later.
"Our most gloomy budget prediction in 2009 was about right," Mr Daley said.
"The scale of these errors – larger than the ultimate deficit in most years – calls into question a do-nothing budget strategy that justifies deficits on the basis of a projected surplus or near surplus at the end of the forward estimates period."
